BAKER PRESSURES BEIJING

Opening talks in Beijing, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d asked Chinese leaders to halt any transfers of nuclear arms technology to countries like Algeria and Iran and release political prisoners. 3 HOW TO PUNISH LIBYA

The White House indicated that it would pursue diplomatic means before considering military retaliation against Libya for the 1988 bombing of a Pan Am jet. Officials talked of a possible oil embargo. 4 PALESTINIAN UNDER FIRE

The Israeli police recommended that Hanan Ashrawi, the main voice of the Palestinians at the recent Middle East peace talks, be brought to trial for supposedly having met with P.L.O. officials. 4 SOVIET ARM SALES STIR FEAR
Pentagon officials fear that Moscow is setting off a wave of arms proliferation by selling weapons and technology for badly needed cash. 5 TURF WAR IN MOSCOW
Like many Soviet officials, Foreign Minister Boris D. Pankin is trying to figure out what his job is and struggling to keep it from being swallowed by the republics. 5 A HINT TO BRITAIN

Ending two days of talks, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany and President Francois Mitterrand of France warned that the European Community must take decisive steps toward unity at a meeting next month.5 DAY BY DAY IN DUBROVNIK

Against a backdrop of medieval walls and tourist hotels, the people of Dubrovnik endure a nerve-wracking siege by Yugoslav gunners. 4 Bacolor Journal: The threat from a volcano is far from over. 2 Fresh acrimony among rival factions in Cambodia. 3 National 6-8, 26 CONVICTIONS OVERTURNED
A Federal appeals court threw out the convictions of John Poindexter, the highest-ranking Reagan Administration official to be found guilty in the Iran-contra affair. 1 THE F.D.I.C.'S BIG LEGAL BILLS
The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the world's largest employer of private lawyers, is wasting much of the $700 million it is paying them this year, two studies say. 1 CHANGING MEDICARE FEES
In the biggest change in Medicare in 26 years, the Government issued a fee schedule that will increase payments to family doctors while reducing payments to specialists. 1 STOCK MARKET PLUNGES

Stock prices tumbled nearly 4 percent, with the closely watched Dow Jones industrial average losing 120.31 points to close at 2,943.20. Biotechnology and insurance stocks were particularly hard hit. 1 2 B.C.C.I. OFFICIALS INDICTED

The Justice Department announced the indictment of two officials of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International and a major shareholder on fraud and racketeering charges. But they are not in the United States, and it is uncertain they can be tried. 1 NO BIG FUN ON THE BAYOU

Louisiana is full of rage and fear in the hours before the gubernatorial runoff between former Gov. Edwin W. Edwards and State Representative David Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan leader and neo-Nazi. 1 REVIEW OF POSTAL WORKERS

A day after a former postal workers killed four supervisors, the postmaster general ordered a review of the personnel records of all the Postal Service's 750,000 workers as well as former employees. 6 IMPACT OF THINNING OZONE

A leading marine scientist said today that the thinning of the atmospheric ozone layer over Antarctica had allowed ultraviolet radiation to penetrate much deeper into the ocean than suspected. 6 EVALUATING AID FOR COLLEGES
Education Secretary Lamar Alexander said he would favor changing the relationship linking Federal financial aid to the accreditation of colleges and universities. 26 EXTRA BENEFITS FOR JOBLESS

The Senate passed and sent to President Bush a bill providing extra unemployment benefits to those who have been out of work at least half a year. It also passed a measure making the extra benefits more generous in some states, but that bill must be considered by the House. 46 Many jobless say a few weeks of extra benefits won't help much. 46 Metropolitan Digest, 21 VIRULENT TB STRAIN KILLS 13
